title: Between 1 April 2018 and 31 March 2019, will an armed group from Mali engage in a campaign that systematically kills 1,000 or more civilians in Mali?
preds: Thousands of Malian citizens marched through the streets of Bamako in an opposition-organized protest to demand a free and open presidential election slated for July and equal access to state-run media for all candidates. Unlike the previous demonstration at the beginning of June, this one went off peacefully, thanks to a UN- and AU-brokered agreement between the government and opposition. Jeune Afrique (in French) notes that the demands of the demonstrators extended beyond the election to include denunciations of the current government, calls for economic reform, and an end to corruption. These types of widespread demonstrations in the run up to presidential elections in Africa are commonplace, and the fact that outside agencies were able to get the government to show flexibility and restraint bodes well for a peaceful outcome.Nevertheless, given the volatility of country,the situation warrants continued monitoring. http://www.jeuneafrique.com/575299/politique/mali-plusieurs-milliers-de-manifestants-defilent-a-bamako-pour-reclamer-des-elections-transparentes/
The contry is to happy no ? 🐬

Two attacks attributed to Fulani groups affiliated with IS in northern Mali killed 17, and 47 respectively in the past weeks as tensions rise between the Fulani and the Tuaregs who are assisting French forces fighting against extremists. The Fulani reported a Tuareg-led attack that killed 44 on April 27. The UN reports 95 extrajudicial killings in the Menaka region since the beginning of the year. As French-led forces conduct their counterterrorism operations in the region, intercommunal tensions are growing. Mali is also set to hold presidential elections on July 29.  https://www.news24.com/Africa/News/17-killed-by-isis-linked-extremists-in-malis-northeast-20180504 https://www.longwarjournal.org/archives/2018/05/analysis-conflict-within-a-conflict-in-malis-northern-menaka-region.php

The spread of instability and security vacuum in the north of the country continues apace resulting in the growth of local militias and terrorist groups.  Social breakdown is also fueling the simmering crisis which has been described as the most dangerous UN peace keeping mission.

Very much worth a read regarding possible paths to escalation by the EWP itself: "The Simon-Skjodt Center’s research aimed to identify the scenarios in which Mali could plausibly experience large-scale, systematic attacks on civilians, and to explore ways to help avert these scenarios. The report focuses on varieties of “worst case” scenarios in Mali not because they are highly likely— these are in fact very low probability events—but because their impact would be extreme. We selected Mali for this study because our annual global risk assessment has consistently placed it in the top 10% of countries, ranking 9th, 13th, and 8th out of 162 in 2014, 2015, and 2016, respectively. The report was informed by interviews with 93 interlocutors from the Malian government, armed groups, civil society, and domestic non-governmental organizations (NGOs) in Mali as well as country experts working in government and NGOs internationally. This report is one of the components of the Early Warning Project, which includes both quantitative and qualitative assessments of atrocity risk. Virtually every study on the subject has identified early warning as a critical component of mass atrocity prevention, determining that intervention is more likely to be successful the earlier it begins. This report is the third in a series of deep-dive qualitative assessments designed to assist policymakers, NGOs, and members of civil society in understanding the atrocity dynamics particular to the country in question and recommending preventative actions." https://www.ushmm.org/confront-genocide/cases/mali
